name: Melbourne
fun_fact: Fun fact: Melbourne is considered Australia's coffee capital with world-class caf√© culture! Proud Mary, one of Melbourne's iconic caf√©s, is ranked as the fourth best coffee spot in the entire world. The city has over 200 nationalities, creating an incredibly diverse food scene!

hero_dishes.name: Melbourne Brunch Culture
hero_dishes.description: Elevated all-day brunch featuring innovative dishes like peanut butter waffles with chocolate and orange yoghurt mousse, smashed avocado toast, ricotta hotcakes, and fusion creations blending Asian and Western flavors.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Melbourne pioneered the brunch-as-an-art-form movement, with caf√©s treating breakfast and brunch with the same creativity as fine dining. This culture emerged from the city's obsession with quality coffee and transformed into elaborate all-day dining experiences.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Higher Ground (in a stunning heritage-listed building in the CBD) dishes up elevated caf√© dining all day. New Korean caf√©s like Trbl on Presgrave Place blend French technique with Asian flavors, serving Korean salt bread, matcha croissants, and injeolmi cheesecake alongside savoury options.

hero_dishes.name: Laneway Dining Experience
hero_dishes.description: Hidden caf√©s and restaurants in Melbourne's narrow laneways serving everything from European-style caf√© fare to Italian/Asian fusion, often with outdoor seating and street art backdrops.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Melbourne's laneways were once forgotten alleys, but have been transformed into vibrant dining precincts where food, culture, and community merge. These spaces reflect Melbourne's multicultural heartbeat and creative spirit.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Degraves Street features cosy European-style caf√©s serving exceptional coffee and pastries under caf√© umbrellas. Hardware Lane offers lively Italian/Asian fusion dining with outdoor tables under city lights on red-brick paving.

hero_dishes.name: Multicultural Fusion Cuisine
hero_dishes.description: Melbourne's immigrant history creates a melting pot of authentic cuisines from Italy, Greece, China, Vietnam, India, and beyond, often fused in innovative ways.
hero_dishes.origin_story: With over 200 nationalities represented, Melbourne's food scene has been shaped by waves of immigration. From Italian eateries on Lygon Street to authentic Asian restaurants in Richmond and Footscray, particularly Vietnamese on Victoria Street.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Richmond's Victoria Street is famous for authentic Vietnamese restaurants. Chinatown offers authentic Chinese street food from dumplings to fragrant noodle dishes. Lygon Street remains the heart of Melbourne's Italian dining scene.

signature_drinks.name: World-Class Melbourne Coffee
signature_drinks.description: Third-wave specialty coffee treated as both an art and a science, with each cup carefully crafted using meticulously selected beans and innovative brewing techniques.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Melbourne caf√©s have set the global standard for coffee appreciation. Proud Mary (ranked 4th best coffee spot worldwide) pioneered the cool, third-wave caf√© movement. Locals take their coffee seriously - flat whites, piccolos, and batch brews are common orders, not just generic lattes.

food_culture_notes: Melbourne has set a global standard for coffee culture, treating coffee as both an art and a science
Laneway caf√©s offer brunch for around AUD 20-30 including coffee, while formal dinner restaurants average AUD 35-60+ per person
New coffee shops like Trbl are defining a new era blending Korean caf√© culture with local suppliers like Dukes Coffee
Many eateries lean into sustainable practices: vegan, vegetarian, gluten-free, and organic alternatives
The city hums with creativity fueled by over 200 nationalities, giving it a distinct European flair in architecture and caf√© culture
Degraves Street is officially recognised as a pedestrian laneway famous for alfresco dining, caf√© culture, and street art
Richmond is known as lively and multicultural, especially for Vietnamese cuisine on Victoria Street
Fusion of culinary traditions is common: Korean bakery caf√©s blend French technique with Asian flavours
Melbourne's caf√© culture extends beyond coffee to elaborate brunch dishes that rival fine dining

landmarks: Graffiti-covered laneways with hidden caf√© entrances
Degraves Street with alfresco dining under umbrellas
Hardware Lane's red-brick paving with outdoor tables
Heritage-listed buildings converted into caf√©s (like Higher Ground)
Victorian-era architecture mixed with modern street art
atmosphere: Intimate laneway dining with outdoor heaters and umbrellas
Urban tapestry of street art, caf√©s, and community spaces
European-style caf√© culture in an Australian setting
Multicultural neighborhoods with distinct culinary identities
Creative, artistic energy in converted warehouses and heritage spaces
Communal tables and bench seating in trendy caf√©s

Korean-Australian caf√© fusion (Korean salt bread, matcha croissants, injeolmi cheesecake)
Forgotten alleys transformed into dining destinations

Brunch elevated to an art form with Instagram-worthy presentations
